text: Hi this is David from MinuteEarth.

If you wanted to design the perfect predator,
you’d make it huge, impossibly strong, incredibly

fast, and capable of freezing its prey as
it approached.

And we've actually built pretty much that
very thing: a car.

And while cars aren’t car-nivores, every
day they mow down millions of animals - and
that doesn’t even include insects.

All this death, though, has an unexpected
upside: the car-casses are actually a bone-anza
for scientists.

Not because scientists are morbid, but because
they're resourceful.
Like, say you wanted to survey hedgehogs.

Normally, you'd have to tromp through well,
hedges, night after night, maybe dragging

along expensive equipment, just to find the
elusive critters.

And to gather information about individual
hedgehogs, you’d have to use fancy traps,
and get special permits.

Or you could just find them flattened on the
pavement, document where you found them, gather

the specimens, and study them to your heart’s
content.

In fact, roadkill has actually helped us learn
all sorts of stuff about our planet.

Scientists in Southern Europe have found more
smooshed snakes earlier and earlier in the

Spring, suggesting that the rising temperatures
caused by climate change are drawing them
out of their burrows sooner.

In the Everglades, a sudden lack of wrecked
raccoons, squashed opossums, and battered

bunnies indicated that something was amiss
- and that something turned out to be invasive

pythons nomming all the inhabitants of the
swamp before they could even get to the road.

And by studying the bowels of plowed owls,
we found that pesticide-laden rats make up

a large portion of the diet of many birds
of prey - putting even non-squashed raptors
at risk.

But different animals don’t all get flattened
with the same frequency, right?

Doesn't this make it harder to draw scientific
conclusions from roadkill?

Owls for example don’t seem to notice cars,
which makes them relatively common victims.

Pronghorns, on the other hand, speed up when
crossing the road, making them less likely

to get hit, while bats detect and avoid traffic
altogether.

On the other end of the spectrum, armadillos
tend to freeze when cars approach, so they're
extra likely to get mowed down.

And since scavengers like crows like to nom
on flattened fauna, they often end up flattened
too.

But as long as scientists understand this
variation, they can account for it in their
analysis.

OK, so this is all a little morbid and a lot
depressing, but roadkill ecologists are simply

following in the footsteps of other opportunistic
researchers, like marine biologists who search

through fishing boat nets to find new deep
sea dwellers.

Or engineers who study storm-damaged structures
to identify better building materials.

Or the archeologists who excavate mass graves
to reveal the mysteries of ancient civilizations.

Or the astronomers who study the remains of
star explosions to understand the laws that
govern our universe.

They’re simply part of the grand tradition
of scientists who turn car-nage into knowledge.
